Introduction 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is an X-linked disorder affecting red blood cells (RBCs).  G6PD catalyzes the rate-limiting step in the pentose phosphate pathway, which produces NADPH in the cytosol of RBCs, protecting them from oxidative damage (

figure 1
).  Without G6PD, cells are prone to episodes of acute hemolysis under oxidative stress.

Pathophysiology



The pentose phosphate pathway, also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt, plays an important role in protecting cells from oxidative damage.  This pathway generates NADPH, which cells use to maintain a steady supply of reduced glutathione, an antioxidant that can neutralize free radicals (eg, superoxide anion, hydrogen peroxide) (

figure 2
).  Without NADPH, glutathione remains in an oxidized state and cannot detoxify free radicals.  Mature RBCs, which lack nuclei and organelles, are particularly dependent on the pentose phosphate pathway because it is the only mechanism for them to generate NADPH.



G6PD, the rate-limiting enzyme within the pentose phosphate pathway, has a half-life of approximately 60 days, which is enough time for RBCs to maintain adequate levels throughout their 120-day lifespan.  However, mutations in the gene that encodes G6PD can cause it to become less stable, resulting in a significantly shorter half-life.  In addition, because RBCs lack nuclei, they cannot synthesize additional G6PD for replacement.  Therefore, G6PD activity rapidly declines until it is completely absent, often well before the RBC reaches the end of its lifespan.



Without sufficient G6PD, oxidative free radicals cause hemoglobin to irreversibly denature and precipitate into insoluble Heinz bodies (inclusions attached to cell membrane) (

figure 3
).  Heinz bodies reduce erythrocyte flexibility, and these rigid RBCs become trapped in the reticuloendothelial system.  Once trapped, splenic macrophages remove the Heinz bodies, leaving irregularly shaped RBCs known as bite cells (
image 1
).  After the "bite," the irregular edges may seal together, forming blister cells (
image 2
).  Splenic macrophages can also phagocytose the trapped RBC (ie, extravascular hemolysis).  Rigid RBCs are also susceptible to intravascular hemolysis as they attempt to traverse narrow capillaries.  During these episodes of acute hemolysis, lysed erythrocytes release heme into the circulation, resulting in:



  • Hyperbilirubinemia:  Heme is catabolized to bilirubin, causing scleral icterus and jaundice.
  • Hemoglobinuria:  Heme is excreted by the kidneys, causing dark urine.

Risk factors



G6PD deficiency is the most common RBC enzyme disorder, with the highest prevalence among those of Asian, African, or Middle Eastern descent.  Multiple genetic variants have been identified, each with an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern.  All males (46,XY) who carry the mutation are affected because all RBCs have the genetic variant.  Females (46,XX) who carry the mutation (heterozygotes) are typically unaffected because random inactivation of the X chromosome (lyonization) results in approximately 50% of RBCs with the genetic variant.  However, acute hemolysis can occur in females with biallelic mutations or skewed lyonization.



The genetic variants primarily differ in length of half-life of G6PD, and the susceptibility to hemolysis varies accordingly.  Most patients with G6PD deficiency are asymptomatic until exposure to oxidative stimuli overwhelms the reductive capacity of older RBCs.  Common oxidative stimuli include:



  • Medications (eg, antimalarials, sulfonamides) (

    )
  • Foods (eg, fava beans, which are metabolized to oxidative compounds)
  • Infection (activated leukocytes release reactive oxygen species)

Clinical presentation



Most patients are asymptomatic until oxidative stimuli (eg, medications, foods) overwhelm the reductive capacity of older RBCs, triggering acute hemolysis that manifests clinically with signs of hyperbilirubinemia (eg, scleral icterus, jaundice) 2-5 days after exposure.



Patients can also develop signs of anemia (eg, dyspnea on exertion, pallor, fatigue) and hemolysis (eg, jaundice) and back/abdominal pain (likely related to free hemoglobin binding nitric oxide, triggering smooth muscle dystonia).  In addition, patients can also develop hemoglobinuria (in which urine dipstick is falsely-positive for blood [due to heme] but there are no erythrocytes on urine microscopy).



In some cases, G6PD deficiency can present with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and anemia in neonates.

Diagnosis



The diagnostic evaluation of suspected G6PD deficiency involves the following laboratory tests (

figure 4
):

Complete blood count



Complete blood count with reticulocyte count and RBC indices:



  • Decreased hemoglobin concentration
  • Normal mean corpuscular volume
  • Increased reticulocyte count due to compensatory accelerated RBC production

Hemolysis testing



  • Increased lactate dehydrogenase
  • Increased indirect bilirubin due to excess bilirubin production that overwhelms hepatic conjugation
  • Decreased haptoglobin (binds free circulating hemoglobin)
  • Negative direct antibody (Coombs) test (excludes immune-mediated hemolysis)

Peripheral blood smear 



  • Shows Heinz bodies, bite cells, and blister cells

Confirmatory testing



  • G6PD activity in RBCs:  Enzyme levels can be measured directly.  Measuring a patient's G6PD activity during acute hemolysis can yield falsely normal results because the RBCs with the most deficient G6PD activity (ie, the oldest RBCs) have already lysed.  Only the remaining younger RBCs with relatively preserved G6PD activity will be measured.  If there is suspicion for G6PD deficiency, testing should be repeated 3 months after the acute hemolytic episode.  Direct measure of G6PD activity may also be used to screen for patients at risk for G6PD deficiency prior to treatment with oxidant drugs.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of G6PD deficiency includes:



  • Other inherited hemolytic anemias:  Like G6PD deficiency, these disorders present with clinical findings of hemolysis (eg, jaundice, anemia).  However, distinguishing features include the following: 

    • Other RBC enzyme disorders (eg, pyruvate kinase deficiency):  Pyruvate kinase catalyzes the last step in glycolysis (
      figure 5
      ); without mitochondria, erythrocytes rely solely on glycolysis for ATP production.  Patients with pyruvate kinase deficiency develop chronic (not episodic) hemolysis, hepatosplenomegaly, and pigmented gallstones.
    • Hemoglobin disorders (eg, sickle cell disease, thalassemia):  Can be distinguished from G6PD deficiency by RBC morphology (eg, sickled RBCs (
      image 3
      ), target cells (
      image 4
      )).  In addition, thalassemia is characterized by ineffective erythropoiesis (inappropriately low reticulocyte count).
    • RBC membrane disorders (eg, hereditary spherocytosis, hereditary elliptocytosis):  Can be distinguished from G6PD deficiency by RBC morphology (eg, elliptocytosis (
      image 5
      ), spherocytosis (
      image 6
      )).
  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemias (eg, alloimmune hemolytic disease of the newborn, autoimmune hemolytic anemia):  Antibodies bind RBC membrane surface receptors, resulting in hemolytic anemia.  The opsonized RBCs are recognized by splenic macrophages that remove the immune complex and surrounding cell membrane.  Loss of cell membrane surface area results in spherocytes, not bite or blister cells.  In addition, immune-mediated hemolytic anemias can be distinguished from G6PD deficiency by positive direct antibody (Coombs) test. 
  • Other causes of neonatal jaundice:
    • Benign neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, breastfeeding failure jaundice:  Because G6PD deficiency can present with indirect hyperbilirubinemia shortly after birth, it can be difficult to distinguish from other causes of neonatal jaundice.  Anemia and abnormal RBC morphology raise suspicion for an inherited hemolytic anemia.
    • Alloimmune hemolytic disease (AHD) of the newborn (ABO incompatibility):  Similar to G6PD deficiency, AHD of the newborn can cause anemia and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.  However, in contrast to G6PD deficiency, patients with the disease  develop jaundice the first 24 hours of life.  In addition, AHD of the newborn can be distinguished from G6PD deficiency by positive direct antibody (Coombs) test.

Management



Management of acute hemolysis associated with G6PD deficiency is primarily supportive, involving immediate removal of the inciting oxidative stimuli, aggressive hydration, and blood transfusions as needed.  The acute hemolysis typically self-resolves within 1-2 weeks of removal of the oxidative stimuli.  Patients should be counseled on how to avoid common oxidants.



Management of neonatal jaundice associated with G6PD deficiency is also supportive (eg, hydration) but often involves phototherapy and/or exchange transfusion in more severe cases.

Prognosis



The severity of illness depends on the underlying genetic variant.  In general, the prognosis of G6PD deficiency is favorable with strict avoidance of known oxidative stimuli and proper management of acute hemolytic episodes.

Summary



Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency (

) is an X-linked disorder characterized by episodes of acute hemolysis under oxidative stress.  G6PD catalyzes the rate-limiting step in the pentose phosphate pathway, the sole source of NADPH, an essential reducing agent, in red blood cells (RBCs).  Without sufficient NADPH, RBCs undergo acute hemolysis when exposed to oxidative stimuli.  Management of acute hemolytic episodes involves supportive care (eg, hydration, transfusions); patients should be counseled to avoid known oxidative triggers.
